posts.com:
Advice on making a successful advice post on /o/:

If you are looking to get advice on a possible car purchase or car related problem, be sure to include:

What car or cars you are looking at or as detailed a description of the problem as possible. Include make, model, year, mileage, condition, any know faults, the asking price, and what your budget is!

If people have to ask you for every detail, you aren't going to get many replies!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1.)Get financing ahead of time/know your credit. You always want to have a financing option in hand before you go to a dealership. Nothing wrong with negotiating a better deal with them once you get there, but never go in empty handed. This way you can have idea of how much you can afford to spend, and what a car is going to cost you

2.)Do your research. Know what values KBB/NADA/Edmunds/TrueCar are listing for the cars you are interested in. Also know what other dealerships are listing similar cars for. Dealerships will prey on the uninformed, so make sure that you are

2b.)If you don't know enough about cars to inspect one yourself, arrange to get any used car inspected or bring someone who DOES know what to look for. It's surprisingly easy to polish up a turd and get it passed inexperienced eyes

3.)Never take the first offer, unless it's a place like CarMax that doesn't negotiate. Dealerships know the game, and they always get a certain number of people to bite on the first offer. make them work a little to get your business

4.)You can negotiate on more than the price. Oil changes, services plans, warranties, accessories are all fair game.

5.)In today's world, internet sales departments are your friend. You can send a blanket email to 3 or 4 dealerships and get them to compete for your business, let them haggle with each other before you ever haggle with them

6.)Get them to print you a Buyers Order for any car you are seriously, that is what you negotiate from. It will look like pic related, and itemize every line of the sale. Don't let them 4 square you or hand write shit on a piece of paper. Get a buyers order

7.)Never be afraid to walk away from a deal. If you have a bad feeling, sleep on it. There will always be other cars

>>26269609
People have the same problem with their loved ones. Euthanasia and getting people off life support have massive resistance and stigma when in a lot of cases it's the humane thing to allow the person to pass away when their time comes. But we keep them alive chained to a bed, possibly in a ton of pain, even though they themselves would want to already go because we're not ready to accept reality.

I've seen enough people with late stage cancer, dementia, etc. suffer just because their families aren't willing to accept that their time has come. And what do they gain in the end, couple more months of "life" where they're stick in a bed, in a lot of pain, and alone for most of the time because the same people that are too afraid to let go don't bother to visit them.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26270851
Online is typical for the reason most car testers don't have the motorcycle spark plug hole adapter sizes. About forty bucks should get a decent one.

The testers are simple Bourdon tube gauges (read how those work, theory of operation is key to knowledge) which are simple to use. Remember to hold the throttle fully open and have removed all four plugs to reduce resistance and go easy on starter and battery.

Shane Conley is a skilled instructor (I've trained many techs in aviation) so I recommend his videos. Look over his vids so you've an idea how to inspect.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l4du6Z8Dw3w

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26270406
You've never done one then. They are not hard but they are absolutely not easy and will take several hours to do, and this is coming from someone who has probably done 5 or 6 by now.

Not a dealbreaker IMO, my understanding is once you've fixed it it's not an issue again. It's just one of those things you need to think about when considering the price of whatever car you buy. It's a simple job to do step-wise but it seems every bolt is pointing the wrong way for you to reach or connectors require careful fiddling to disconnect. I have big mechanic sausage fingers and it makes removing the belt sprocket bolt annoying.

Oh yeah and to explain to those who don't know the 2.0 thermostat/coolant pump:
It's a mostly plastic body with a metal pump bolted to it on the transmission side - the pump being driven by a tiny timing belt off the balance shaft which sticks out towards the rear of the engine for this purpose. I've never seen a pump go bad but everyone I've seen has codes for the thermostat (either sensor or actuator). Basically the thermostat is 100% computer controlled and has a valve body which can control how much coolant goes to the block and head. My guess is coolant makes it past the valve's seal and into the motor/circuitry.

Hope this helps

posts.name: BigC

>>26259740
here's the instructions copy pasted, you keep making a fool of yourself lol
1. Place the boards in their fully deployed position. In most cases, it may be easier to remove the motors from the motor linkages to allow the steps to fully deploy, and proceed with the rest of the process.
2. Verify that the pinch weld holes are lining up with the holes for the linkages. You may need to enlarge the holes in the pinch weld if they do not line up or are catching the bolt threads as you install the steps.
3. Verify that the rear of the running board is flush with the rear linkage. If it is not, adjust the running board forward so that the end cap is flush with the linkage.
4. Make sure that ALL HARDWARE IS TIGHTENED PROPERLY.
5. Have someone walk the length of the board, taking bouncing steps or shifting their weight up and down as they walk. DO NOT JUMP on the running boards. Only shift your weight up and down while moving the entire length of the running board, like you are performing a suspension check.
6. With the boards still in the down position, loosen the button head Torx head bolts that go through the pinch weld. DO NOT loosen the hex head bolts on the back of the rocker panel. Then, either have someone sit on the center of the board or put some weight on the center of the board. While there is weight on the board, retighten the button head bolts going through the pinch weld.
7. Remove the weight from the board, and try moving the board up to the completely stowed position. Check to see if the board clears the pinch weld. If it clears, reinstall the motors and complete the installation. In some cases where the pinch weld is more uneven, you may need to do this complete procedure a second or third time. If the step still does not clear the pinch weld after several seating attempts, please continue on to Step 8.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26267153
That sure looks like a standard positraction clutch-style limited slip. Are the clutches not pictured, or are the two washers there supposed to be it?

I've ran a fistful of them and they're okay. They have a fixed torque break-out, which makes them less ideal than a variable LSD (Torsion, Power-Lock, Gov-Lock), but still a good option. It'll want to drive a straight line until the clutches slip which makes driving it a bit odd around suddenly tight corners or when one tire hits ice while the other is still on pavement.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26267153
If you're taking the diff apart, weld it, mini spool, or auto locker. I've never seen blocks be an option since mini spools are in the $100 range, or a professional auto welder who's done a hundred diffs would be in the $100 range, an auto locker is in the $400 range, or a helical diff (truetrac or substitute) are in the $600 range. An auto locker is a locked diff, that can ratchet when you're not putting power down, a truetrac isn't locked but it's about the tightest lsd you can get.
tldr: no

the Dodge brothers owned 10% of Ford Motor Company but did not yet themselves have a car business.
Henry Ford heard they were planning to start one (using the dividends from HIS company no doubt made his very upset), so to throw a wrench in their gears he attempted to divert dividend payouts back to his own pocket, claiming it would be for increased wages and factory upgrades. They sued him and won.
The Supreme Court of Michigan ruled that a company's purpose is to make money for the people invested in it, not to operate as a charity.
The problem largely comes from Ford's ill-thought out use of specifically the investment dividends to make up this cost, he was in effect stealing money he rightfully owed to people who gave it to him expecting a return. Seemingly charitable, but really a cover for corporate sabotage.

2: Vehicles are a gimmick used only largely on this map, but the difficulty is interesting at least with mud/snow mix. I like the verticality of this one.
3: One of the better areas for starters because the oversized trailers can actually be used rather well here. Hope you like mud, but probably next to Alaska in ease. Vehicles here are kind of nice.
4: It's Season 1 but with even more dickheaded design. You do get the best superheavy truck on this level to compensate. Just like 1, I wouldn't come here until you have better equipment.
Year 2:
5: Distilled bullshit starting off. Not as bad once you get the tempo down and get out some decent ground clearance trucks. Trucks unlocked here are okay but nothing to note since you probably have a decent lineup by now.
6: Gimmick is a Hardcore-Lite mode until you progress far enough, in which is just becomes like 2 but easier. Trucks you get here are good but unlock way too damn late.
7: Easily and without a doubt the single worst DLC of the game. Not really tough but extremely lacking content and feels like recycled assets from the Dakar game they (then) recently released. Vehicles really only work on this level and nowhere else in the game, and the whole level is so short with content you could 100% it in a session or two.
8: Tries to redeem the failure of 7 by adding four massive areas to drive around in. Might be easier than 3 in terms of difficulty.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26257785
Premiums:
Navistar 5000-MV: It's just the BOAR from 3, but with slightly worse fuel usage and a military look. This was the preorder DLC which dominates Michigan/early game, but very quickly falls off later.
Brigadier: This is just a slightly fancier version of the GMC truck you get from Michigan. It's an okay performing truck but I wouldn't really say it's mandatory or good except if you want to be a completionist.
Chevy Apache: Similar to the Navistar in that it's like a truck you will get later on (YAR in vanilla) unlocked earlier to dominate early game.
CAT CT681/International HX 520: Arguably the best premiums because of being free, they make excellent support trucks. The CAT 681 when upgraded with a good engine and highrange is one of the best trucks in the game for moving quick.
Western Star 49X: A big fat heavy truck that is only really good for pulling large trailers. Will fuck you if you play Hard mode due to the extra maintenance costs.
Tatra 813/805: You'll get this one automatically on buying the Year 1 pass. 805 makes for a very good heavy offroad truck until you get a larger toolset to use. Personally used it for the GOAT Zikz on Season 4.
Jeeps: Mediocre scouts with not much ability, even to haul trailers. Might be fine in light dirt but are very useless to do anything serious.
Crocodile: Makes for a good resupply truck, one of the better premiums actually. Similar to the trucks you unlock in Season 1 but without the suspension problems.
Western Star Pack: Aesthetically a cool pack with the 57X, but by this point you've seen this trucks already and have trucks with much better performance considering these are highway/light vocational trucks.
Hercules: Like the Apache, but without the ability to pull a trailer.

>>26257785
>>26257786
My quick and dirty unofficial guide to starting off:
>Fuck off out of Michigan, head to Russia to beeline it to the Tayga repair mission
>Repair the Tayga, take it back with you to Alaska
>Run some missions in Alaska until you're at a decent enough money/level to start affording better tires
>You want to get off highways ASAP, it'll become a lot easier to deal with thick mud after that point
>In (almost) every case, I is better on road, III better on dirt, and II in mud, so swap to IIs if you get stuck often
>Almost all chains are identical, performing like All-Terrains in mud and Offroads in dirt
>You can force a transmission to act as a semi-automatic by clicking the gear shift to force the transmission to shift for you (mandatory for some of Season 7)
>Pacific trucks despite the lack of AWD have some of the best traction values for tires, best tires in the game are on the heavy Russian scout in the final vanilla region
>Highrange transmission does reduce fuel usage slightly even when idling, while Advanced transmission increases it
>If you have yet to complete the Season 4 DLC or know someone who needs to complete the Season 4 DLC, see if you can find a party trying to unlock the Zikz as it along with the Tayga will carry you through the hardest parts of the game

>>26257888
Nah, this game is an absolute dickpunch starting off, especially because Michigan is really muddy until you figure out alternate routes to go around. Alaska has icy roads but those shouldn't be too much a concern if you keep moving. Know at least one person in my group that negatively reviewed it due to being such an early game clusterfuck and I had to carry them through around their first 10 hours of gameplay.

The Tayga along with the Zikz will carry you through the game, don't feel bad about making them your bread and butter until you learn fancier tricks in getting around.

>>26257920
Not really? Lot of the premium trucks are actually not that good, the CAT CT681 is one of my most used trucks because it's got an incredibly power/weight ratio and highrange slams through all but heavy mud and snow, and best part is it's free. If it was still early on you could argue the Navistar is an unbalanced preorder truck but it too has problems like no diff lock and chugs fuel like a motherfucker. Play it similar to the CAT by slamming it in high on highrange and letting it boulder through terrain rather than sink in. Even with just the Year 1 pass the game dumps the Bandit on you and the 805, which is more than enough to get the Zikz.

>Lake Kovd
It is a tough area, but it really is a very pretty area and the borealis at night also helps. I like it and have done decent time there, but it's not a beginner friendly zone. Will have to play through Season 8 more with bad trucks because that may be one of the easiest regions to play in the game now.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26245261
Could be a number of things but the most likley is that water (which is a byproduct from combustion) is precipitating in your cold exhaust pipe, and that when your exhaust heats up (as the engine does) it makes it out the end of the exhaust still in gaseous form. What you're seeing is condensation, not smoke. If it is smoke it could be your piston rings that seal better as your engine internals heat up, which causes your cold engine to consume a bit of oil.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26248477
We'll start with the most serious issue: The cracked block.
If it was cracked externally, you'd doubtless have found the leak by now.
If it was cracked internally, you definitely notice symptoms such as fluid contamination. Given you state that's not happening, nor is it building too much pressure, then I'm optimistic you can rule out the block/head/head gasket.

Likewise, if the EGR manifold/cooler assembly has started leaking, you'll be able to tell as exhaust gases would be present to some degree in the coolant, darkening it. If not darkening it, then a sniffer test would detect the presence of coolant. They're a simple kit to buy and use.

Failing that, we're left with the wet intake manifold as the most likely cause of the three you've listed.
Testing it (and the EGR manifold, if it comes to it) is easy - if a little awkward.
Basically block one pipe, and find some way to fit a tyre valve to the other. Inflate to 20 psi, use water/suds to make sure your pipe block/valve arent leaking and observe any pressure drop. Over, say, half an hour. A leaking component will have lost it's pressure.

Or you can remove the components completely, then submerge them like a tyre tube and look for bubbles.

Also, take out your spark plugs. If it's the EGR or the intake, then ALL the plugs should have signs of burning coolant.
If only one or two plugs have it, then it's an engine issue.
The coolant-fouled plug is on the right

posts.com:
>>26249695
As per >>26249793, I'd start with the right oil. The cold index at 5 is fine, but the hot index - at 30 - is less than the 40 recommended, meaning lower oil pressures at operating temps.

Because it only happened once, I wouldn't worry too much about it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Does it help or hinder tire alignment that electric cars have 4 independent motors instead of one motor/driveshaft powering all the wheels? Debating with a friend, one of us thinks it's easier because each wheel can have sensors and adjust alignment as needed, one of us thinks it's worse because there's nothing mechanical keeping the system in sync.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26251509
>Electronic on-the-fly wheel alignment adjustment
Jesus I can't think of anything more horrifying. Luckily, I don't ever see that happening on mass market vehicles; the alignment will be held rigid by threaded bolt members or bolted eccentric cam washers.
Having four wheel motors won't have any effect on that setup because the motors will be "inboard", meaning they drive the wheels from inside the sprung mass of the vehicle, dividing the torsional stress of acceleration between the motor's mounts, the driveshaft and the suspension mounts.

Even if the motors were all hub mounted, the only thing it would do is increase the stress of acceleration on the suspension mounts, making them more likely to wear earlier, which could *then* impact alignment.
Stronger components/bushings would negate that, however.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26250095
On the 122, it's not really so simple. There's a manifold block that bolts to the side of the head, and this block is where the hot coolant flows out of the engine from and into the radiator. The thermostat housing bolts onto it, and it has the ports for the coolant level and the coolant temperature sensors. And also the EGR gasses flow through it (it does have vacuum modulated EGR). But, closing off the EGR valve would only prevent the EGR gasses from continuing into the intake, it would NOT prevent the EGR gasses from entering this manifold and potentially entering the coolant loop (if there is a crack here). So "ripping out the EGR" would involve at minimum some kind of blockoff plate custom made for the shape of this manifold, and the shadetree tools I've got don't extend to a mill. But believe me, I've thought about it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26264482
>I'll try but again I think the battery and the power is fine.
The battery might be fine, but if it's not getting to your starter because of a bad battery cable it's not going to help you. I guess I'd measure the voltage to the connection marked S (the skinny wire) while someone cranks the key inside. If it's 12V the problem is your power wire, the ground strap from the engine to the body, the ground cable from the body to the battery, or the starter itself is shot. You can eliminate the grounds as a potential cause by running a jumper from the negative of the battery to the starter housing and see if it still won't start.

If you're not getting 12V on the S connection, possible culprits are neutral safety switch or ignition switch.

Just an idea, you did try taking it out of park and putting it back in kind of hard right in case your NSS isn't quite engaged?

When looking at radio waves and antennas you need to understand how a VHF signal resonates, and how it would be impossible for an internal antenna to resonate on proper fm frequencies. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Pennzoil NISMO GT-R invasion at 2001 NISMO FESTIVAL!

2001 was a rad year! It was a rare and unique opportunity to see all the Pennzoil-sponsored NISMO GT500 cars together. And let me tells you: the legendary american oil brand stopped to sponsor one of two NISMO official team chassis in 2000 JGTC season, but returned to 2001 for sponsor the ex-LOCTITE ZEXEL GT-R car, becoming the ‘Pennzoil ZEXEL GT-R’ that year. Different from the 1998 R33, and 1999 R34 Pennzoil GT500 champions, and even helping NISMO to win the 2001 season on team standings along with the sister chassis, the Pennzoil ZEXEL GT-R has been updated to ‘Castrol PITWORK GT-R’ for 2002, losing the yellow livery and the Pennzoil sponsor once again. So yes, it means that the Pennzoil ZEXEL GT-R is no longer around us.

Another curious fact, , is that the Pennzoil NISMO GT-R BCNR33 and BNR34 pictured here aren’t “original” cars, but replica based on other chassis. Respectively, they are the 1998 ZEXEL SKYLINE and 1999 CALSONIC SKYLINE repainted as Pennzoil-sponsored cars for NISMO’s heritage.

The original Pennzoil BCNR33 has the low-downforce kit and Nicos GT banner and sometimes can be seen appearing in some events, including the NISMO FESTIVAL itself. The original Pennzoil BNR34 however, has been lost. It was upgraded to ‘Castrol NISMO GT-R’ for 2000 JGTC season, but the car crashed in the first round, being replaced by a new bespoke chassis. NISMO took the IMPUL’s BNR34 late that year to replicate the 1999 JGTC GT500 drivers champion.

>>26259466
A historical racing team named French Speed Connection has bought a JLOC Murcielago and a Taisan Viper (can't remember which year), they're restoring them and plan to race them in the Endurance Racing Legends championship taking place around Europe.
Unfortunately most JGTC/Super GT cars have either been dismantled or stored in some warehouse/yard and collecting dust and/or rust. Sometimes they're put up for sale to free up room, or auctioned off (recent examples include the Jim Gainer 360/430, #666 Bomex Avanzza Vemac, one of the 986 Boxsters that ran in GT300). Another interesting case is the Dijon Racing GT300 Corvette, it ended up being converted to a drift car by Daigo Saito

posts.name: laseranon
posts.com:
>>26252371
I actually couldn't tell you when they stopped using them, but I know they were developed in 1940, and this hearse is a '52, so they had quite a good run. The rest of the guts of the transmission are actually pretty solid and easy to work on, but I dispise the viscous coupling design. When pulling the motor or the trans, you have to drain 7qts out of the coupling and remove the nearly 40 bolts from the flywheel. And when re-installing it, you have to be absurdly careful to not bump or tear the thin paper torus gasket or you'll get the mother of all leaks since it's under a lot of pressure from the centrifugal force of the fluid spinning in the coupling.

posts.name: laseranon
posts.com:
>>26252611
It's not a torque converter since there is no reduction from the input to the output. It's just a viscous coupling that allows slippage between the front and back for the trans to shift while still being able to transfer power 1:1. There isnt a serperate rotor on the inside like there is in a TC, its just two halves of fins that rotate close to each other. So yeah, its more like a clutch, I suppose. That's not unique to this trans though, I've worked on a few others that have the same thing. Here's one out of a 50s Daimler I did a while back.
I doubt GM invented the concept, but I know they're definitely the first ones who ever used it in a production car.

posts.name: laseranon
posts.com:
>>26253207
A torque converter has a stator and has the ability to multiply torque at the output, sort of like a gear reduction. They're usually around a 2.5:1 reduction. A viscous coupling does not have a stator and can't multiply torque, it's best ratio is 1:1.
Also, >>26253215 is right. A torque converter uses the actual flow and direction of the fluid to transmit torque to the stator fins, whereas a viscous coupling simply uses the shear force of the fluid. I would assume it transmits power less efficiently than a torque converter, but I genuinely don't know.
>>26252978
Maybe, but I dont really think so. A torque converter gives the engine more mechanical advantage, especially if you're engineering a small economy car with a small engine.

>What are the issues?
Personally I think its a treat of a motor to work on...in a TR7, in a Saab it might be a different story.

As for problems
>Waterpumps like to fail, you will notice this looking at the weephole in the block its a day long job your first time as the intake has to come off.(A 3 hour job once you have pulled those intakes a few times, there are also some other things of note when working around the intake, pulling a waterpump.)
>Headgasket failure, buy a quality replacement gasket if you have to do a headgasket, it shouldn't fail unless the car has been overheated. Its a dog of a job if your head hasn't been removed in 40 years(mainly headstuds), but possible.
>Timing chain, it should give an audible warning before failure but its a hell of a job in a Saab I imagine.
>Idk what hell your fuel delivery system is on that thing. Either a single stromberg or KE jet I imagine.
Oh and 99 transmissions are...glass, and replacement parts are....a pain, but there is some autist guy in....Kentucky(?) I think who can get you parts. Almost bought a 99 that was owned by him or his kids or something.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26266950
>everyone hates the factory V12
Only those that can't handle anything but a SBC

>Corvette motor
Schmaybe. Pic related is a center-bolt valve cover L98 Corvette engine. Notice the valve covers are painted, not chrome. That intake is a TBI from a 90's pickup, as is the distributor (L98's had HEI) and the cast iron exhaust manifolds. That accessory drive set up is also 90's pickup. Note the difference in alternator mounting for one. Now it could be an L98 under all that other stuff but Occam's Razor suggests that they simply swung a 90's 5.0/5.7 TBI truck engine in there as being the simplest explanation. I also see a 700R4/4L60 TV cable there below the accelerator cable so it's got Overdrive at least. Not that it needs it, the original rear axle ratio is 2.87 iirc. Luckily you can get center sections up into the mid 4's if you want (and it probably desperately needs).

Also, not impressed by the cooling fan install that has poor coverage due to no shroud.

I might pick up a used nu-Ranger when this bullshit pricing ends. Any complaints about it? Hows the MPG?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26261328
MPG is meh, about 18 around town and 23 on roadtrips. (Those are actual calculations btw, not what the trip computer claims.) To be fair that's 4WD with A/T tires at relatively low pressure though, more street-oriented models should be a little better, and it's still better than other comparable midsize trucks. Mine needs a battery so the start/stop isn't working (really common issue with these, the stock batteries only last 2-3 years for some reason) and it might be a bit better with that fixed as well, people on the forums say it actually makes a couple of MPG difference on the Ranger.

Other than that I'm really happy with it. My only real complaints are about things that were available but not ordered by the original buyer, like the leather steering wheel, heated seats, sliding rear window, LED headlights, etc. Other than that the transmission can be a little clunky at times but no big deal, the suspension gets a little bouncy over specific road surfaces but that's an FX4-specific issue and replacement shocks are pretty cheap, the stock tires were trash but you're gonna replace those eventually anyway, etc.

A protip if you want one, see if there's an Avis dealer near you. Mine came from them and it was relatively high mileage for the year but exceptionally well-maintained, no bullshit upsells or anything from the dealer, and they've got really good no-haggle pricing, I got the top of KBB for my trade and well under KBB on the truck and didn't have to fight for it at all.

Ferrari 355 is possibly my favorite car of all time that isn't unobtanium. They have apparently shot up in price recently, probably because Jewtubers won't shut the fuck up about them, but I'd never buy one because the $5-$10k engine out service you have to do every 5-10 years for the fucking timing belt even if you barely drive it. Yes, think of it like a soap and wax in one. You mix one ounce with about a gallon of water, soak a rag in it, and wash with that rag without rinsing the car. Do one small section at a time. While that section is still wet, use a microfiber cloth to dry and buff it.

EVs by contrast are often paying the equivalent of $1.17 a gallon equivalent in higher registration fees, and $.87 a gallon equivalent in tax on fast charging.

You may not like it, but EVs are happening unlike every other alternative to fossil fuels because they do not require subsidies. The only reason the tax credits for EVs exist today is to slightly offset the effect of the distortion of fossil fuel subsidies to level the playing field a little bit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Deals on these and most used cars are harder to come buy but they still exist. What I would consider a deal for an e46 would be under 150k miles, has been garaged or put in storage during winter so minimal rust, has evidence of preventative maintenance done or receipts for parts installed, and is under 6-8k depending on it’s motor and body configuration. The m54 are pretty stout but start burning oil around 150-200k miles because of the control rings. The m52tu motors found in the earlier 328i have better control rings so they don’t burn oil. Other than that and the subframe issue already mentioned there isn’t much that catastrophically go wrong with these cars unless they’re neglected on maintenance.

If all e46’s were driven by enthusiasts who like to get on it pretty often I’d agree but majority of the autos and specs below zhp’s were driven by average people who don’t launch their cars from stoplights. It’s the high torque from the 330’s and up that put more pulling force on the weak metal above the subframe that make it more susceptible to cracks and tears. I’d only say it happens to every model if your purpose is to try to make it happen by dry launching it all the time but how many axles are you gonna snap to get to that point.

>>26258013
How so?
EV are great for daily live and for people that can charge slowly at home
But for workers and long trips I see Hydrogen ICE (and fuel cell) as a possibility
An EV has about 280liters of battery space below the seats, convert that to hydrogen tanks and it's about 220l = 9kg at 700bar (180kg tanks)
On a fuel cell that's 500-700miles range, on a ICE it's 350-450miles
With the predicted (2030) 6$/kg H2 at the pump that's 8-10$/100miles on fuel cell or 12-14$/100miles for ICE
All without CO2 and NOx emissions (direct injection, EGR, lean burn)
Even if it's stupid... people would buy just for the feels

>>26267136
>What doesn't fuck up the engine?
Using the proper RPM range without high revving cold engine. Any real car enthusiast can feel(unless you are stereo all the time) and hear it if you are lugging the engine at too low RPM's because the engine doesnt pull smoothly at all. Instead the engine pulls constantly jerky and does have very poor throttle response, also often you can hear some unusually loud valve tapping noise from engine at same time. Dumb people think that all engines give them performance benefits for redlining the engine while in reality most of stock, properly designed, efficient engines actually loose power when redlining the engine resulting to slower acceleration.

>>26269837
Batteries in current generation BEVs are already robust enough to last the normal life of a vehicle 20 years / 350k miles.

Odds are by the time you might think about replacing the battery pack, better packs will be available cheap.
Like how swapping the 24kWh pack out of an old leaf and upgrading it to a 40kWh pack only costs a few thousand dollars (unless you want to keep the old pack).

Older generation BEVs suffered from the problem of availability more than anything else, now that there's millions of some specific EV models on the road long term maintenance is more likely to be a thing.
The ~25k Model 3 SR+ starting to show up on the market now are likely to be one of the best performance bargains of the decade. The newer base Model 3s are heavier and slower.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26264070
You can get a Miata that low really easily. Good aftermarket coilovers + springs, then for additional low feeling get a proper bucket seat instead of that piece of shit Mazda used. For steering, get a powered steering rack and then depower it. It has a much quicker ratio than the factory manual rack. Put a smaller diameter steering wheel on, stiffen up the chassis, get good wheels and tires, do some mild weight reduction, and you're good to go. Not quite as sharp as an Elise or Exige, and certainly not as powerful (until you tarbo it), but still great. Problem then is that the car is so capable that it's kinda boring to drive on the street at non-reckless speeds

But yeah if you don't want to go through all the bullshit of modding the Miata, just get an Elise. It's a more complete and cohesive package from the factory...a lot of mechanics won't touch em though, at least here in the PNW. A friend of mine in the Portland area has an Exige and there's literally one mechanic who will do oil changes, and they're expensive
>>26262980
also a solid choice

>>26264528
A lot of the additional weight for the NB2 comes in the form of chassis bracing that you need to add anyway if you're trying to make the car handle better. Aftermarket bracing might be lighter than the shit Mazda used, I dunno. Also in the US the NB1 was sold in California and Federal flavors, and you want Federal. NB2 just has one emissions spec. It also has a buncha other improvements. Shedding weight is pretty easy
>strip trunk and dump the stupid spare
>lightweight battery
>replace seats with buckets (stock seats are like 35lb each)
>stereo delete (it's useless)
>AC delete (it doesn't do anything either)
>lightweight wheels
TWS T66-F forged 15x7 are 10lb a corner, stock 16s are like 17 per and fucking suck anyway, this is a massive improvement
>xida coilovers save like 10lb
>wilwood brakes save another 10-25 depending on which oem brakes you have
>chuck the shitty softtop for a hardtop (some orgs require this for track shit)
>lexan windows

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I have both a Miata and an Elise.

Miata has turbo, suspension, chassis stiffening etc. I thought the Miata felt like go kart but the Elise is on a different level

Elise pros:
Steering / handling is amazing
Mid engine rotation is fun
Locks of course
Toyota VTEC
Weight
Elise cons:
Pain to work on because mid engine/clamshells
Clam are expensive and easy to damage. A fender bender will often total the car, the front clam is also Liberty to scrape because it is so low
Cost both upfront and in parts

Miata pros:
Cheap both to buy and maintain
Amazing aftermarket and easy to work on
Because it's cheap, I'm less worries about driving it around. I daily mine now.
Still an amazing drivers car, but not on the same level as the Elise.
Miata cons:
Gay?
Not mid engine (can be good if you are leaning)

If you are just using the car for weekend / track and can afford it Elise is very fun.

Otherwise, Miata is still great but FR. If you want a good mid engine car for cheaper, zzw30 mr2 is like 85% of an else for like a 5th of the price

I also did workforce training for toy money after going back to school for fun (CNC machining and welding to get better at building vintage motorbikes) and we had companies BEGGING instructors for references because getting someone who could show up on time and pass a piss test was apparently insanely difficult. Even in backwards SC there are about two jobs for every worker but qualified (genuinely, not HR babble) people are hard to find.

BTW the oil patch uses chemists. My skilled jet mech bro did eight years in service then bolted and is making bank mixing/monitoring chems for fracking sites.

I've seen your strategy work for a very long time. My father was a successful management consultant because he hated working for a regular boss. Every contract was like switching jobs but he was good and never lacked work. Medical techs and therapists often work on the road too. My sister had her pick of jobs before settling in Santa Barbara working on rich people.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26268628
high pumping and line losses would make it very inefficient. a lot of the energy put into this system would be converted to heat due to fluid shear - before locking torque converters this was basically how transmissions worked and they were much less efficient than with locking.
also, since a modern transmission uses gears placed after the torque converter you can easily increase the torque to the wheels without increasing the max "pressure" or fluid shear within the converter.
the system you're proposing would have a direct correlation between line pressure and wheel torque assuming a static impeller size at the axle; to achieve similar wheel torque to a traditional axled vehicle i'm guessing the line pressure would be prohibitively high.

t. mechanical engineer

>planning to store some extra gas in the trunk.
Changes in temperature cause the gasoline can to breathe out fumes. In an enclosed trunk, there could eventually be enough fume concentration from either a cheap or a leaking gas container/nozzle assembly. Some trunks, like mine, have electronics with relays (thus spark).

If you do have a quality gas container that is well braced along with a cord tie down across its handle to keep it from tipping over, then you can carry it in the trunk. But why do you feel a need to carry gasoline?

Instead of a container, Just top off your car's gas tank as you drive past another gas station. There are plenty of stations everywhere. I like to stop and top off the tank because it also gives me a chance to get out of the car to strech my legs and walk around a bit.

Actually gas cars in cold weather at high speeds use even more energy relatively speaking. It just makes less of a difference to you because you're already so inefficient and probably won't even notice.
50 Wh/mi difference from annual average to winter average for an EV is a 22mpge difference. 1% high energy consumption for a Model 3 at 350 Wh/mi is a 39mpge difference.
50 Wh/mi difference for a gas car is barely a 1 mpge difference 1350 -> 1400 Wh/mi.
Even a 350 Wh/mi difference, more than the EV is using total in winter, will still barely register as a 5mpg difference 1350 -> 1700 Wh/mi.

The only advantage ICE cars have today is gasoline is heavily Government subsidized, and its not an issue for a gas car burning more energy from its 500 kWh tank.
Affordable BEVs still haven't even hit 100 kWh. But when they do that's a car that can easily go 80 for 300 miles even in most cold weather.

>>26263575
My Brother bought a Natural Gas Iveco Daily similar to pic because emissions laws near London were getting ridiculous, and it was a fucking nightmare. Power-wise it was okay, but it just kept having reliability issues, the worst of which being that it would burn out valves some reason. Think he had them replaced 3 times at 3 different specialists, and they couldn't figure out why it was doing it. Fueling was fine, ECU mapping was correct, no problems logged in the computer... Just cursed. SPent nearly 4 grand on the thing before he sold it off to some bloke up north who was confident he could fix it. Good riddance. Oh, and the few places you could refuel it at were miles apart, so if you were near empty and where you drove to was out of gas, you'd have to tentatively drive to next station and hope they weren't ALSO out of gas.

Only works if gas is cheap but fuel is expensive. Saw tons of those in South America, they work fine, the older generations were hard on the car if you didn't run on gas from time to time, but the more modern systems alternate automatically so you never have problems with carbon build up.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26263890
It was Australia wide.
Private conversions weren't super popular but "factory" Holden/Ford converted dual fuel systems (Holden ones were technically done by HSV because of liability issues iirc) were actually extremely popular.
Reliability was great, power loss was minimal (and sometimes was gained on dedicated LPG setups), and paying less than half the price of patrol for like 10% worse mileage AND still having the option to switch between both in an instant was extremely appealing.
In SA petrol stations that serve LPG are becoming harder to find as they can't justify the build or upkeep of the special pumps, and rural areas are basically getting cut off by the gas supplier because its not economically viable.
I think its a fucking shame, because it burns cleaner, has a higher octane and is dirt cheap. My dream car is a manual HSV VF wagon on dual fuel - but that won't help me if I can't buy LPG.

(1/2)
Wondering if anyone had a similar issue with their shitbox as I'm running out of ideas.
2010 mazda3 1.6d, manual, stutters randomly at any rpm above 1.5k and I can't diagnose the problem.
First of, car is otherwise running perfect, fuel economy is 5.6l/100km as it should, power is all there and she hauls plenty for that small engine, can redline easy and she also idles dead straight on 900rpm. Starts up at half a turn. Turbo is fine, injectors are fine, pump I assume is fine, fuel filter checked and changed, all fuel lines inspected and all the wiring too. Air intake and vacuum lines checked. New battery and alternator as the old alternator died recently. Also exhaust gasses are within spec as I had her tested in the road test center.
Now the first problem.
Car will stutter randomly when driving. Usually it's like 3-4 stutters that are pretty violent, feels like the whole engine cuts out, she will keep driving normally after that. It can happen once in an hour of driving or every other minute. Sometimes it's so often I feel like she will just die on the road. That's any rpm as long as you are accelerating or the car accelerates herself (to keep the speed), no difference whether engine is cold or under optimal temperature. Outside factors are also irrelevant, it doesn't matter if its cold, hot or raining. Funny thing is you can make her stop stuttering not only by releasing the pedal but also flooring when she stutters first. I've played around with it and I believe it's not the pedal acting up in a certain position.
pic related

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Now the reason why it's so hard to find the problem.
The stuttering comes and goes, she's been having this problem for over a year and good 60% of that time she was fine.
It almost happens like in waves, she will be all perfect for like a month or so, then she will stutter once. Next time driving maybe twice or trice. Up until she's stuttering like like she's about to break down. Then it will get rarer and rarer until the problem disappears for a few weeks. Then it will start again.
I've been in 4 different mechanics shops and everyone is just shrugging their shoulders. This problem rarely if ever shows when you are revving it in neutral, got her to stall in neutral only once. It feels like the engine needs to be under load for this to happen.
Only code I have is DPF system. God knows what part of it exactly as she have the DPF fluid tank underneath and I have filled up the liquid, It wasn't out btw. How could it be DPF system if all it does is spray the cat? Also why would she be fine for weeks and then start stuttering for another few weeks, just to start working good again?
I haven't bought a new DPF system as I can't find a used one to just swap and I have no clue what part of it is acting up to buy a new parts as the scanner can't show anything more substantial than "DPF system fault".
Any ideas?
Same engine should be also in Focus and 306 I think

>>26266306
If you make enough money to get the full federal credit, you make too much money to get any of the big state level rebates, retard.
The federal credit isn't refundable, so to get it you need to simultaneously have at least $70k in income; not be reducing your tax in any way through a 401k, IRA, HSA, child tax credit, etc. etc,; but also not be over the $150k income limit for the credit. If you're married, it's even worse and you need to be well into the six figures. If, like most Americans, your income tax liability is already basically zero, you get none of that money. The amount is also being cut for Teslas delivered after February, so you better hope they can deliver it in time, or else you'll get even less.
The only state level credits that are even close to $6k from your own link are expired or limited to literal poverty level buyers. Like you need to simultaneously make less than $36k a year, yet own a house in San Francisco or San Diego, AND be able to put down $45k in cash to buy the car. If you're that kind of unicorn, you already get none of the federal credit. Almost all the generally available rebates are for a few hundred dollars, a handful are $1-2k.
And that's before you still need to pay sales tax, insurance, registration, interest... all based on the sticker price.

I just sit on it. You can kinda tell the ergos via cycle ergo if you compare it to other bikes you rode, but it's all an estimation.

>How do you ride your bike when it's raining?
Waterproof gloves, waterproof overpants, a neck sock and just my regular jacket and boots. It's quite nice, in a lot of ways I prefer the rain to hot weather.
>What do you do when your butt gets wet?
At that point everything has already soaked through and there's nothing you can do. So it's best to just force yourself to relax and not let the cold make your muscles tight, because that could make you ride dangerously.

>>26267428
Better long term reliability and cheaper costs, better engine sound ,also no annoying turbolag. Turbos break much easier than engine, lets say if theres an oil leak and you dont notice it on time. It takes only 5 seconds for turbo to break down due to lack oil, while for engine it can take 5 minutes to break down due to lack of oil. If theres crack at the air intake it takes only a small amount of dirt to cause huge damage to the turbo blades. When bad turbo leaks oil it can damage/clog the catalytic converter as result you have to replace both turbo and catalytic converter.

Turbochargers generally dont last long as the engine does. Naturally aspirated engines can last double amount of miles than turbocharged engines, choosing naturally aspirated engine prevents lots of headache for the driver in the long run.

I have 15K miles on my 1LT and if you have your mirrors adjusted outward (which you should anyway) it isn't an issue at all.
>>26264851
>Z51 is the one package that *is* worth it
Not for a daily driver that won't be tracked.
>more expensive tires that don't last as long and lose a ton of grip if the road is wet
>larger brakes with track compound pads that squeal and get dust on everything
>stiffer springs and anti-roll bars that make the ride worse on the road
>aero that adds drag and not much else at roadgoing speeds
>an electronic LSD that doesn't provide any benefit on the road
>brake ducts that you don't need unless you're going all out
>a transmission cooler that you don't need on the road
>a higher final drive ratio that reduces fuel efficiency to help to get a massive 0.1s improvement in 0-60 time
I had Z51 (with aero delete) on my build until the last day. I'd really like the bigger brakes in spite of the noise and dust, but they can be added later and I haven't needed them for twisty mountain roads. Plus you can get the performance exhaust without Z51 anyway.
>>26266347
>brakes that instantly explode when you drive by a track
The only thing you should add for extended track sessions on the Z51 is higher temp brake fluid. The smaller brakes and street pads on the base car shouldn't be used on a track.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Like other people said, just suck it up and put money down on a proper one, the chink ones may work or they may leak fuel everywhere, you are the QC with those things.
I've heard people use fajs DGV clones for E30 BMWs with success over here, but I still wouldn't trust one.
I believe they make adapter plates specifically for jap engines, so that shouldn't be an issue.

Now what you should mind is fuel pump pressure, DGVs are quite pissy about fuel pressures and will bust the needle valve if the pressure is too high, usually they like it around 0.2-0.3 bar or about 3psi or so, anything above that and you'll have to drill out and tap a return line opposite of the fuel intake line to lower the pressure or fuck around with a fuel pressure regulator.
